questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department with abdominal pain and nausea for the past 24 hours. The pain started a few hours after dinner, and he describes it as a constant pain in the upper part of his abdomen that radiates to his back and flanks. The patient also reports nausea, intermittent vomiting, and abdominal distention. Family history is significant for recurrent episodes of pancreatitis in his father and paternal uncle. He reports drinking an average of 2 alcoholic drinks per week. His temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, peripheral oxygen saturation is 96%, and blood pressure is 149/94 mmHg. He appears distressed and anxious. Abdominal examination shows tenderness and rigidity over the epigastric and periumbilical regions. Bowel sounds are diminished. No bruising of the umbilicus or flanks are seen. Which of the following laboratory results is the most specific in diagnosing this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Serum amylase > 3 times the upper limit of normal
Serum lipase > 3 times the upper limit of normal

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with constant abdominal pain localized in the epigastric region that radiates to the back, highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis occurs when pancreatic enzymes are inappropriately activated, leading to tissue damage and an inflammatory response. This patient has a family history of recurrent pancreatitis in his father and paternal uncle, suggesting the diagnosis of familial hypertriglyceridemia, an autosomal dominant condition. The high concentration of serum triglycerides can cause acute pancreatitis because when pancreatic cells encounter triglycerides, they release lipase to break the triglycerides down into free fatty acids; excess free fatty acids can subsequently injure the pancreas.  

The most common causes of pancreatitis are gallstones and alcohol toxicity. The other causes of pancreatitis can be easily remembered by the mnemonic “I GET SMASHED”:  



To make a diagnosis of acute pancreatitis (from any cause), one needs 2 out of 3 of the following criteria:  
  •  clinical symptoms, such as persistent, severe, epigastric pain with tenderness on palpation 
  •  laboratory studies demonstrating serum amylase or lipase greater than 3 times the upper limit of normal; lipase remains elevated for a longer period of time and has a higher specificity as compared with amylase 
  •  imaging (computed tomography, magnetic resonance (MR), ultrasonography) showing focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas 
In this patient with a characteristic clinical presentation, the demonstration of an elevated serum amylase or lipase level will confirm the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. However, serum amylase may be spuriously normal in patients with hypertriglyceridemia and spuriously elevated in patients with acidemia (arterial pH ≤ 7.32), therefore serum lipase is the preferred laboratory test for diagnosing acute pancreatitis. It is important to note, however, that there is no correlation between the severity of pancreatitis and the degree of serum lipase and amylase elevations. Additionally, an elevation in serum triglyceride levels is not sufficient to diagnose acute pancreatitis. Hyperbilirubinemia, leukocytosis, azotemia, and hypoglycemia are suggestive of more severe disease, but are not themselves diagnostic of acute pancreatitis.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Serum amylase > 3 times the upper limit of normal:
Incorrect: Although serum amylase elevation may be used to show biochemical evidence of acute pancreatitis, it is affected by serum pH, lipids, and bowel inflammation, and is prone to false elevations or spuriously normal results. Therefore it is not the most specific in diagnosing this patient’s acute pancreatitis.  
✅ Serum lipase > 3 times the upper limit of normal  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum bilirubin > 4.0 mg/dL  :
Incorrect: Although hyperbilirubinemia may occur in up to 10% of patients with acute pancreatitis, bilirubin elevations are not specific to pancreatitis and do not contribute to the diagnosis. Serum bilirubin levels return to normal in 4-7 days.  
❌ Elevated blood alcohol leve:
Incorrect: Although alcohol abuse may cause acute pancreatitis in a dose-dependent manner, this patient only consumes 2 beers/week, which is unlikely to cause acute pancreatitis. Instead, his underlying familial hypertriglyceridemia is likely the cause of pancreatitis.   
❌ Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level > 22 mg/dL:
Incorrect: Azotemia (BUN >22 mg/dL) suggests more severe pancreatitis that is causing vascular permeability and intravascular volume depletion or hemorrhage. However, azotemia is not specific for acute pancreatitis and is not included in the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of abdominal pain and fatigue. His symptoms began 4 months ago and have progressively worsened. In addition, he reports a 5 kg (11 lb) unintentional weight loss since symptom onset. The patient often wakes up at night drenched in sweat. Past medical history is notable for peripheral vascular disease and alcohol use disorder. The patient has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Physical examination shows jaundice and scleral icterus. Abdominal pain is most prominent in the epigastric region. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Total bilirubin  5.2 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  4.6 mg/dL 
 Alkaline phosphatase  96 U/L 
 Aspartate transaminase  110 U/L 
 Alanine transaminase  112 U/L 
 Lipase*  95 U/L 
*Normal range: 12-70 U/L  

Which of the following additional findings will be most likely present on this patient’s physical examination?

choices.text: Tenderness to palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant
Enlarged gallbladder that is nontender to palpation
Diffuse velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has pancreatic cancer, which is typically located at the pancreatic head and can cause jaundice. The most common type is pancreatic adenocarcinoma. It arises from the epithelial cells lining the pancreatic ducts. It is a very aggressive tumor, and individuals often already have metastases at the time of diagnosis. Important risk factors include smoking, high alcohol consumption, and chronic pancreatitis.  

Patients with pancreatic cancer can have epigastric pain, weight loss, fatigue, and night sweats. Patients can also have Trousseau syndrome (also known as Trousseau sign of malignancy) and Courvoisier sign. Trousseau syndrome, also termed migratory thrombophlebitis, is characterized by blood clots that appear unexpectedly in superficial veins, and then over time migrate to different locations in the body. Courvoisier sign describes an enlarged, palpable, yet non-tender gallbladder and accompanying jaundice.  

Laboratory testing can show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (due to bile duct obstruction by the tumor), elevated liver enzymes, and alkaline phosphatase. Lipase may also be elevated. A frequently tested fact is that tumor markers associated with pancreatic adenocarcinoma are carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA).  



Option Analysis

❌ Flank ecchymosis and discoloration:
Incorrect: This answer describes the Grey-Turner sign, which is seen in patients with acute pancreatitis. Pancreatitis causes epigastric pain that radiates to the back and markedly elevated lipase levels. This patient’s history of alcohol use disorder does put him at greater risk for pancreatitis, but it would be atypical for acute pancreatitis to cause chronic fatigue, weight loss, or night sweats.
❌ Tenderness to palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant:
Incorrect: Murphy’s sign is characterized by tenderness upon palpation of the right upper abdominal quadrant. This sign is associated with cholecystitis, which can cause abdominal pain and hyperbilirubinemia. However, it would not account for the elevated lipase or liver enzymes. 
❌ Periumbilical discoloration and bruising:
Incorrect: This describes Cullen’s sign, which is another physical exam sign found in patients with acute pancreatitis. However, it would be atypical for pancreatitis to cause the chronic fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats seen in this patient.
✅ Enlarged gallbladder that is nontender to palpation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diffuse velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin:
Incorrect: This answer describes malignant acanthosis nigricans, a paraneoplastic phenomenon associated with abdominal malignancies. To be specific, it is most often seen in patients with gastric adenocarcinoma. In contrast, this patient’s elevated lipase, liver enzymes, and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia are more consistent with pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right lower quadrant abdominal pain. The pain is sharp, stabbing, and has progressively worsened. He has also had decreased oral intake and an episode of vomiting that has since resolved. Past medical and surgical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), blood pressure is 107/67 mmHg, and pulse is 106/min. The examiner passively extends the patient’s right leg with the patient lying on his left side. This maneuver reproduces pain in the right lower quadrant. Which of the following best describes the physical examination finding present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features of acute appendicitis, including right lower quadrant pain, anorexia, and associated vomiting. Additionally, the pain is reproduced with passive extension of the right hip, consistent with a positive iliopsoas sign (also termed the Thomas test).

The iliopsoas muscle originates on the outer vertebral bodies of T12 and L1-L3. The muscle inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. This muscle is largely responsible for hip flexion and thus is important for standing, walking, and running. Passive extension of the hip places strain on the iliopsoas and any nearby structures or anatomically associated pathology.

Common etiologies associated with a positive iliopsoas sign include acute appendicitis, sigmoid colitis, or lymphadenopathy. Rarely, a positive iliopsoas sign may indicate a psoas abscess, which is a collection of pus in the iliopsoas compartment. When these conditions are suspected, definitive diagnosis is best achieved with a contrast-enhanced CT.  

Option Analysis

✅ Iliopsoas sign:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Murphy sign:
Incorrect: Murphy sign is performed by pressing firmly in the right upper quadrant, having the patient inspire, and then exhale slowly. A positive test indicates worsened pain with expiration and can signify underlying cholecystitis.  
❌ McBurney point tenderness  :
Incorrect: McBurney point tenderness is elicited by palpation at McBurney point, which is one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. Tenderness at this location suggests acute appendicitis.  
❌ Rovsing sign  :
Incorrect: Rovsing sign is performed by palpating the left lower quadrant. The test is positive if left lower quadrant palpation elicits pain in the right lower quadrant. A positive test can be suggestive of acute appendicitis.  
❌ Homan sign  :
Incorrect: Homan sign refers to reproducible pain with forced dorsiflexion of the foot. A positive test can be indicative of lower extremity deep vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe sharp right upper quadrant abdominal pain that radiates toward the right lower thoracic back. The pain began that morning. The pain in the back is not improved or worsened with movement. Her symptoms are accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), blood pressure is 150/78 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. On physical examination, pain is elicited upon deep palpation of the right upper quadrant. Which of the following nerves is most likely responsible for this patient’s referred back pain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. These findings are concerning for acute cholecystitis. This patient’s pain in the right upper quadrant is due to irritation of the gallbladder and is considered somatic pain, which refers to pain located directly at the site of injury (e.g. pinprick on the skin).    
The patient is also experiencing referred pain to the back due to visceral referred pain. Referred pain is located away from or adjacent to the organ involved. Patients with acute cholecystitis often experience referred pain in the right lower thoracic spine, ribs, and right shoulder.   

Referred visceral pain occurs due to spatial and temporal summation of general visceral afferent (GVA) pain fibers. GVA pain fibers follow sympathetic nerves back to the preganglionic sympathetic fibers. As these preganglionic sympathetic fibers route to the spine and central nervous system (CNS), the CNS is unable to perceive the spatial location of the pain since it is lost at the level of the nerve ganglion. As a result, the pain is poorly localized and often referred to the dermatomal areas innervated by the same spinal level as the autonomic nerve supply. Consequently, when there is abdominal pathology, foregut pain is usually referred to the epigastrium, midgut to the umbilicus, and hindgut to the pelvis or hypogastrium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Greater thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lesser thoracic splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the midgut
❌ Lumbar splanchnic nerve:
Incorrect: This nerve provides sympathetic innervation to the hindgut
❌ Sacral nerve roots S2-4:
Incorrect: Sacral nerve roots S2, S3, and S4 provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the foregut and midgut. In contrast, pain fibers typically travel along sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe abdominal pain. The pain started approximately eight hours ago and was initially located in the periumbilical region. The pain increased in severity and became more localized to the lower right abdomen. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. Using the image below, which of the following best identifies the location where this patient will be most tender with deep palpation?
questions.solution:
This young patient presents with abdominal pain that originated in the periumbilical region and subsequently became more severe and migrated to the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. These findings are concerning for acute appendicitis.     

Appendicitis occurs due to obstruction and inflammation of the appendix. Initially, the visceral afferent fibers are stimulated and poorly localized abdominal pain or pain around the umbilicus is seen. As the appendix becomes more inflamed, the adjacent parietal peritoneum is irritated, and the pain becomes more localized to the right lower quadrant. On examination maximal tenderness with deep palpation at McBurney point will be seen. McBurney point is located two-third of the distance between the umbilicus and the right anterior superior iliac spine. Pain with deep palpation in this region is highly concerning for acute appendicitis and is called McBurney sign. Follow-up imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT) should be obtained for further evaluation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Location 1:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Location 2:
Incorrect: Appendicitis can initially manifest with referred pain in the periumbilical area, represented by location 2. However, the pain will often localize to the right lower abdominal quadrant. Maximal tenderness will be experienced with palpation at McBurney point, represented by Location 1, which corresponds to the base of the appendix  
❌ Location 3:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology.
❌ Location 4:
Incorrect: Pain and tenderness in the suprapubic region indicated by Location 4 can be due to processes affecting the pelvic organs (e.g., cystitis, endometritis). In contrast, this patient’s history and physical examination are concerning for acute appendicitis, which may present at first with referred periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower abdominal quadrant. In acute appendicitis, maximal tenderness with deep palpation is typically seen at McBurney point, represented by Location 1.  
❌ Location 5:
Incorrect: Pain around the anterior superior iliac spine is not commonly associated with an intra-abdominal or intrapelvic process. Instead, pain in this location is more likely due to a musculoskeletal etiology. Left anterior superior iliac spine pain or tenderness is not typically seen with acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage IV cholangiocarcinoma, for which she is receiving chemotherapy. Periodically, the patient develops ascites, for which abdominal paracentesis is performed. However, the patient was lost to follow-up. The patient is brought to the emergency department by her daughter with diffuse abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. On admission, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended and shifting dullness and a fluid wave are present. There is diffuse guarding with abdominal palpation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, and diffuse abdominal pain in the setting of large-volume ascites due to end-stage liver failure caused by cholangiocarcinoma. These findings are concerning for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).    

SBP develops when enteric bacteria translocate from the intestinal lumen and infect the ascitic fluid. This occurs as a complication of liver disease due to increased permeability of the small intestinal wall and impaired immune defense mechanisms. SBP is a common cause of peritonitis which is defined as widespread inflammation of the inner abdomen wall and covering of the abdominal organs (the peritoneum). In addition to SBP, other causes of peritonitis include gastrointestinal tract perforation, infection due to surgical interventions, systemic infection, and pelvic inflammatory disease. Key signs and symptoms of peritonitis include fever, diffuse abdominal pain, guarding, abdominal rigidity, and paralytic ileus.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bacterial infection of ascitic fluid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of nitrogenous metabolites:
Incorrect: Accumulation of nitrogenous waste products, such as ammonia, can occur secondary to liver failure and may cause altered mental status or hepatic encephalopathy. However, hepatic encephalopathy does not cause fever and abdominal pain in the presence of ascites as seen in this case. A better explanation for this patient’s constellation of symptoms is SBP.  
❌ Dehydration:
Incorrect: Large fluid shifts can be seen in patients with end-stage liver disease and they can result in symptoms of dehydration and even nausea and vomiting. However, dehydration would not account for the patient’s fever, abdominal pain, and ascites.  
❌ Tumor lysis syndrome:
Incorrect: Tumor lysis syndrome causes metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia), leading to acute kidney failure, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias. This patient’s fever, abdominal pain and distension, and altered mental status are more likely caused by spontaneous bacterial peritonitis..  
❌ Small bowel obstruction:
Incorrect: Small bowel obstruction can lead to perforation and subsequently peritonitis. However given the presence of shifting dullness and fluid wave indicating ascites and the history of end-stage liver disease in this patient, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is the most likely cause of peritonitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. The patient states that the pain started near the umbilicus yesterday evening, but has since moved towards the lower right side. He also reports that the pain increased in severity overnight, rating it up to a 10 on a 10-point scale. However, he now feels that the pain has diminished slightly. He describes the pain as sharp and states that it was especially bad en route to the hospital when the ambulance drove over bumps in the road. The patient has no past medical history and consumes a vegan diet. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 86/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness over the right lower quadrant. The patient is noted to tighten his abdominal muscles to lessen the pain. Which of the following physical examination signs is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Inspiratory arrest with palpation of the right upper quadrant
Nontender, palpable gallbladder in the right upper quadrant

questions.solution:
This 32-year-old man has severe migratory abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, and right lower quadrant pain. He most likely has acute appendicitis. Additionally, there is evidence of hemodynamic instability (e.g., tachycardia, decreased blood pressure) and abdominal guarding, which means that this patient likely has peritonitis secondary to appendiceal rupture. Patients with peritonitis classically complain of increased pain with sudden movements, such as bumps in the road en route to the hospital or maneuvering of the stretcher. They also might describe a relative decrease in their pain after the appendix has ruptured.  

Appendiceal rupture is a severe complication of appendicitis, as it can quickly lead to peritonitis and sepsis. Vital signs typically show hemodynamic instability, with decreased blood pressure and compensatory tachycardia. Physical exam findings include abdominal guarding, rigidity, and Blumberg sign. Abdominal guarding is defined as voluntary tightening of the abdominal muscles with palpation of the abdomen to lessen the pain. Rigidity is defined as involuntary muscle tightening at rest. Blumberg sign, also known as rebound tenderness, is defined as pain during release following deep palpation.  



Option Analysis

❌ Costovertebral angle tenderness:
Incorrect: Costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness is associated with acute pyelonephritis. This patient’s presentation is more characteristic of appendicitis, which may present with flank pain but not CVA tenderness.  
❌ Inspiratory arrest with palpation of the right upper quadrant:
Incorrect: Inspiratory arrest with palpation of the right upper quadrant, also called Murphy sign, is associated with acute cholecystitis. Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, which can result from obstruction by gallstones or bile stasis. A patient with cholecystitis is unlikely to have signs of peritonitis (e.g. guarding).  
✅ Rebound tenderness :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nontender, palpable gallbladder in the right upper quadrant :
Incorrect: The presence of a nontender, palpable gallbladder palpated in the right upper quadrant, also called Courvoisier sign, is associated with gallbladder or pancreatic malignancy, which would not explain this otherwise healthy patient’s acute presentation with peritonitis.   
❌ Periumbilical edema and ecchymosis :
Incorrect: Periumbilical edema and ecchymosis, also called Cullen sign, is associated with acute pancreatitis. Pancreatitis presents with epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, rather than the classic right lower quadrant abdominal pain of appendicitis shown here.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of diarrhea for the last several weeks. He describes his stool as bulky, greasy, and “tends to float on top of the water in the toilet.” The patient has not had similar symptoms in the past. He also unintentionally lost 11-lb over the past month. He is an avid hiker and most recently went on a hike in the Appalachians, where he regularly cooked his own meat and drank water from nearby fresh-water springs. The patient has not had fever, rashes, or any bloody stools. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a mildly tender abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds. There are patches of skin with hyperkeratosis as well as several bruises. Stool samples are taken and stain positively with Sudan III. If this patient goes untreated, which of the following complications is he most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
This patient has signs of fat-malabsorption (e.g. bulky, greasy stools) as well as symptomatic fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (e.g., hyperkeratosis, bruising). Taking into account his recent hiking trip and ingestion of unfiltered fresh-water, he likely has giardiasis, which is a parasitic infection that results in small-bowel dysfunction.

The fat-soluble vitamins are vitamins A, D, E, and K. Fat-soluble vitamins normally dissolve in dietary fats and migrate through the lymphatic systemic before entering the bloodstream. In patients with fat-malabsorption, this process is interrupted, and over time, a deficiency of these vitamins may develop. The patient in this vignette has signs of vitamin A deficiency, given the patches of hyperkeratosis, and vitamin K deficiency, given the bruising. If untreated, this patient is also at risk of developing vitamin D deficiency, which can lead to poor bone mineralization and increased risk of pathologic fractures.

In suspected patients, a fecal fat test, also known as Sudan III staining, can be used to evaluate for fat-malabsorption.





Option Analysis

✅ Pathologic fractures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sideroblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is used as a cofactor by several enzymes involved in heme synthesis. Vitamin B6 deficiency can impair the addition of iron to hemoglobin. Iron eventually accumulates within the red blood cells, resulting in ring sideroblasts. However, vitamin B6 is a water-soluble vitamin, whereas this patient has symptoms of fat malabsorption. As a result, it is unlikely this patient is deficient in vitamin B6.  
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is heavily involved in energy generation, especially during oxidative metabolism. Since cardiac tissue relies on oxidative metabolism, deficiency of vitamin B1 can lead to cardiac dysfunction and, eventually, dilated cardiomyopathy. Thiamine deficiency tends to occur in patients who are malnourished or have a history of chronic alcohol use.
❌ Adrenal insufficiency:
Incorrect: Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare in humans and can occur during periods of famine in underdeveloped countries. Vitamin B5 deficiency can result in paresthesias, and if severe, adrenal gland hemorrhage and necrosis. However, pantothenic acid is a water-soluble vitamin, whereas this patient has symptoms of fat malabsorption. As a result, it is unlikely this patient has a pantothenic acid deficiency.
❌ Swollen gums and perifollicular hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is heavily involved in collagen synthesis, specifically, hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues during post-translational modification of the collagen protein. The earliest and most specific sign of deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular hemorrhage. Vitamin C, however, is a water-soluble vitamin, and its absorption would be unaffected in this patient who has symptoms of fat-malabsorption.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past five days. During this time the patient has had around six watery bowel movements per day. Medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient was recently treated for a dental abscess with amoxicillin and then clindamycin. The patient drinks only bottled water and has not recently traveled. Temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8 °F), blood pressure is 135/86 mmHg, pulse is 103/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and SpO2 is 100% in room air. On physical examination, there are dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation. Which of the following best characterizes the effects of the bacterial toxin most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of glycine and GABA release
Inhibition of fat absorption from gastrointestinal tract

questions.solution:
This patient has abdominal pain and multiple watery stools per day after a recent antibiotic regimen. These symptoms are likely due to infection by the bacterium Clostridioides difficile(formerly Clostridium difficile), which releases toxins that disrupt actin polymerization.

The bacterium produces two toxins, toxin A and toxin B. The toxins enter cells lining the intestinal walls and cause actin depolymerization, thereby increasing epithelial cell permeability and causing apoptosis. The clinical effects of the two toxins include watery diarrhea and possibly pseudomembranous colitis, which is severe inflammation of the inner lining of the large intestines. Patients with C. difficile colitis must be treated with antibiotics. Care must be taken to wash hands with soap and water, as hand sanitizing solution does not often kill the C. difficile spores.  


Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of elongation factor 2  :
Incorrect: The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits elongation factor 2 (EF-2), leading to the formation of pseudomembranes in the pharynx. It does not cause copious diarrhea.  
❌ Inhibition of glycine and GABA release:
Incorrect: The bacterium Clostridium tetani releases an exotoxin that inhibits glycine and GABA release at the neuromuscular junction, thus causing tetanus. Tetanus is characterized by spastic paralysis, as opposed to watery diarrhea.  
❌ Inhibition of fat absorption from gastrointestinal tract  :
Incorrect: This patient developed new diarrhea after starting an antibiotic regimen, which is concerning for infection by the bacterium C. difficile. Decreased fat absorption is more commonly from chronic processes such as chronic pancreatitis.  
✅ Stimulation of actin depolymerization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Overactivation of adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: Vibrio cholera can cause watery diarrhea via a toxin that leads to overactivation of adenylate cyclase. The bacterium predominantly affects individuals in developing countries who drink contaminated water. This patient only drinks bottled water and symptoms started after antibiotic use.

questions.text: A microbiologist is studying the case report of a young woman who developed sudden-onset emesis and cramping abdominal pain 30 minutes after eating. The patient did not have diarrhea. Which of the following foods is most likely implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Bacillus cereus is a Gram-positive, rod-shaped, spore-forming bacterium. It is aerobic, beta-hemolytic, and catalase-positive.

Reheated or fried rice is an important cause of emetic-type food poisoning associated with B. cereus. The organism is frequently present in uncooked rice, and heat-resistant spores may survive cooking. B. cereus can cause two distinct types of toxin-mediated food poisoning, characterized by either diarrhea or vomiting, depending on which toxin is produced. The diarrheal toxin causes destruction to the intestinal epithelium, triggering the secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. The emetic toxin is ingested directly from contaminated food, which explains why symptoms usually occur very shortly after ingestion of the causative food.

Option Analysis

❌ Canned foods:
Incorrect: Canned foods that are contaminated with C. botulinum can be associated with foodborne illness manifesting as a descending, symmetric paralysis. The onset of any associated GI symptoms is not this rapid.  
❌ Raw oysters:
Incorrect: Consumption of raw oysters can cause infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus, which is characterized by voluminous watery diarrhea.  
❌ Undercooked chicken:
Incorrect: Consumption of incompletely-cooked chicken or raw eggs can cause Salmonella gastroenteritis, which usually causes watery diarrhea but can be bloody.  
✅ Reheated rice:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Undercooked beef:
Incorrect: Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) infection typically occurs after eating undercooked beef and is characterized by inflammatory, bloody diarrhea.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of severe pain affecting several joints. The symptoms began 3 months ago. He has also had loose, greasy stools several times daily as well as a 12-lb weight loss. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is not sexually active and does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/62 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a soft, high-pitched, early diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space. The left and right knee are warm and tender to palpation, and passive range of motion is limited bilaterally. Abdominal examination reveals intense epigastric pain on palpation. Generalized lymphadenopathy is present. Biopsy of the small intestine reveals periodic acid-Schiff-positive (PAS)-positive macrophages within the lamina propria. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Dysregulated immune response to intestinal microbiome

questions.solution:
This older male patient is presenting with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, arthritis, valvular insufficiency, and biopsy results showing PAS-positive macrophages in the intestinal wall. He most likely has Whipple disease.   

This condition is caused by the Gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei, which invades and colonizes many areas of the body, resulting in the wide spectrum of clinical findings. Intestinal manifestation include malabsorption and diarrhea, whereas extraintestinal symptoms include arthritis, generalized lymphadenopathy, cardiac symptoms (e.g. aortic insufficiency), and neurological conditions (e.g., ataxia, oculomotor dysfunction).  

The diagnosis of Whipple disease can be made via a small intestine biopsy showing macrophages that stain positive with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS). Treatment consists of IV ceftriaxone, as well as a year of maintenance therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole given the disease’s high relapse rate.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Infection by Gram-positive rod:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypersensitivity to gliadin:
Incorrect: Celiac disease is caused by an intestinal hypersensitivity reaction to gliadin, which is a component of gluten, and subsequent T-cell activation. While celiac disease may also present with bloating and diarrhea, this patient’s arthritis, cardiac murmur, and generalized lymphadenopathy are not adequately explained by this diagnosis alone.
❌ Increased circulating T3 and T4:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism can result in weight loss and diarrhea. However, hyperthyroidism would not account for the patient’s diastolic decrescendo murmur, which is concerning for aortic regurgitation. Furthermore, this patient’s arthritis and generalized lymphadenopathy cannot be explained by hyperthyroidism.
❌ Infection by Acid-fast staining parasite :
Incorrect: Acid-fast staining parasites that can cause diarrhea include Cryptosporidium species and Cyclospora cayetanensis. Infection with these parasites can cause watery diarrhea, but they would be unlikely to cause the arthritis, valvular insufficiency, or generalized lymphadenopathy seen in this patient. 
❌ Dysregulated immune response to intestinal microbiome:
Incorrect: Dysregulation of the immune system in response to the intestinal microbiome can lead to inflammatory bowel diseases, such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Although these conditions can also present with diarrhea, their endoscopic findings would differ from this patient’s. Crohn disease would show sporadic granulomatous inflammation, whereas ulcerative colitis would show continuous lesions at the rectum. Neither condition would show the presence of PAS-positive macrophages.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic due to watery diarrhea for the last 3 days. The patient returned from Central America last week. The diarrhea is associated with diffuse abdominal pain. Stool studies show Gram-negative bacilli which produce a toxin that resists heating at 60 ºC (140 ºF). Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this toxin?

choices.text: Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating adenylate cyclase
Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by mimicking adenylate cyclase
Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by activating Gs protein
Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by inhibiting Gi protein
Increases cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating guanylate cyclase

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has “traveler’s diarrhea,” which is very frequently caused by enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC).

ETEC causes watery diarrhea and abdominal pain that can sometimes be associated with fever. This process is toxin-mediated. Once the bacteria are ingested, they attach to the gut epithelium and secrete toxins that work in the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to diarrhea. The two toxins produced by ETEC are the heat-labile toxin (LT) and the heat-stable toxin (ST).

ST is resistant to heat. It works by over-activating guanylate cyclase in the gut epithelial cells, causing increased production of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). cGMP inhibits the reabsorption of NaCl, drawing water into the lumen of the gut and causing diarrhea.

LT is destroyed easily by heating. It works by over-activating adenylate cyclase in the gut epithelium, increasing production of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). cAMP in the gut stimulates the secretion of Cl- ions into the gut lumen, drawing water into the lumen of the gut and causing diarrhea.  


Option Analysis

❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of the heat-labile toxin of ETEC.  
❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by mimicking adenylate cyclase:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of the edema factor of the anthrax toxin. Anthrax toxin does not significantly cause diarrhea and it is heat-labile.  
❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by activating Gs protein:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of cholera toxin, which is a heat-labile toxin.  
❌ Increases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by inhibiting Gi protein:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action of the diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin is a heat-labile toxin and does not cause diarrhea.  
✅ Increases cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) production in the intestinal epithelium by over-activating guanylate cyclase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic due to recent-onset nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. It occurred 45 minutes after eating leftover rice and vegetables from a nearby restaurant buffet. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Bacillus cereus is a Gram-positive, rod-shaped, spore-forming bacterium. It is aerobic, beta-hemolytic, and catalase-positive.

Reheated or fried rice is an important cause of emetic-type food poisoning associated with B. cereus. The organism is frequently present in uncooked rice, and heat-resistant spores may survive cooking. B. cereus can cause two distinct types of toxin-mediated food poisoning, characterized by either diarrhea or vomiting, depending on which toxin is produced. The diarrheal toxin causes destruction to the intestinal epithelium, triggering the secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea. The emetic toxin is ingested directly from contaminated food, which explains why symptoms usually occur very shortly after ingestion of the causative food.  

Option Analysis

❌ Giardia lamblia:
Incorrect: Giardia lamblia is usually transmitted by drinking contaminated water. It typically causes foul-smelling, watery diarrhea.  
❌ Clostridium perfringens:
Incorrect: C. perfringens can also cause food poisoning. In contrast to S. aureus and B. cereus, it is late-onset. Its spores germinate in the GI tract and then begin to produce toxins, which explains the pathogens' delayed onset.  
❌ Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli  :
Incorrect: EHEC is characterized by a diarrheal illness that is classically bloody due to its inflammation-inducing properties.  
✅ Bacillus cereus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Shigella:
Incorrect: Shigellosis is characterized by a diarrheal illness that is classically bloody due to its inflammation-inducing properties.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented to the emergency department due to diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past four days. Since symptom onset, the patient has had seven watery bowel movements per day. Temperature is 38.6 °C (101.5 °F), blood pressure is 99/73 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 16/min and SpO2 is 99% of room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and bilateral lower abdominal tenderness to palpation. Clostridioides difficile antigen test is performed and returns positive. Which of the following most likely predisposed this patient to this infection?
questions.solution:
This patient has abdominal pain, watery bowel movements, and a positive Clostridioides difficile (formerly Clostridium difficile) antigen test. These symptoms with the positive antigen test indicate an active C. difficile infection.

Around 5% of the population are asymptomatic carriers of C. difficile. These individuals do not develop colitis and diarrhea since other bacterial species that make up the intestinal microbiome prevent C. difficile from proliferating. However, if the diversity of the normal intestinal flora is disturbed, then organisms that are resistant to many antibiotics – like C. difficile – can thrive while other bacteria die out. The greatest risk factor for C. difficile diarrhea is the recent use of antibiotics, usually broad-spectrum antibiotics, fluoroquinolones, and clindamycin. Only a few specific antibiotics can treat C. difficile infection. Other risk factors include immunocompromised status (e.g. HIV, chemotherapy) and prolonged proton pump inhibitor use.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ingestion of contaminated foods:
Incorrect: This patient has watery bowel movements and a positive C. difficile antigen test. Normally, other bacteria in the intestines prevent C. difficile from proliferating, so it is mostly when other bacteria are killed (e.g. antibiotics) that C. difficile is able to proliferate and cause diarrhea.  
❌ Consumption of unfiltered water:
Incorrect: Pathogens such as Vibrio cholerae or Giardia lamblia can be acquired by consuming unfiltered water. In contrast, C. difficile diarrhea is typically associated with recent antibiotic use.  
❌ Initiation of famotidine therapy:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors can predispose individuals to C. difficile diarrhea, though recent antibiotic use is a much stronger risk factor. H2-receptor antagonists, compared to proton pump inhibitors, are much less likely to predispose to C. difficile.  
❌ Advanced age:
Incorrect: Advanced age and poor immune status can potentially predispose individuals to C. difficile diarrhea. However, recent antibiotic use is the leading risk factor.  
✅ Recent use of oral antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office to evaluate bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Stool culture grows a Gram-negative curved rod. Which characteristics are likely to be found on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bloody diarrhea and stool culture growth of a Gram-negative curved rod that is oxidase-positive. These findings suggest the underlying infection Campylobacter jejuni, which grows at 42°C.

Campylobacter jejuni is a food-borne pathogen that occurs after consuming contaminated poultry, meat, or unpasteurized milk. The incubation period is approximately three to seven days, followed by fever, colicky abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Notably, about half of the children with this infection will exhibit bloody diarrhea. Diagnosis is confirmed via stool culture, and most cases are self-limited.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Grows in 42°C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Grows in alkaline media:
Incorrect: Vibrio cholerae grows in alkaline media, whereas Campylobacter jejuni does not. Vibrio cholerae does not cause bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Produces urease:
Incorrect: Heliobacter pylori is an urease-producing organism, whereas Campylobacter jejuni is not.  H. pylori is a common cause of peptic ulcer disease, not bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Oxidase-negative:
Incorrect: Campylobacter jejuni does produce oxidase (meaning it can use oxygen as a terminal electron acceptor).  
❌ H2S production on TSI agar:
Incorrect: H2S production on TSI agar is a characteristic feature of Salmonella and Proteus, not Campylobacter jejuni.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of large-volume diarrhea for the past three days. The patient has had at least five watery bowel movements per day. She has not had any blood in the stool. Medical history is notable for hypertension, osteoarthritis, and a recent episode of aspiration pneumonia, for which she was prescribed clindamycin. Vitals are unremarkable. Mucous membranes appear dry. No focal tenderness is elicited with palpation of the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents with large-volume watery diarrhea and a recent history of antibiotic use. She likely has Clostridioides difficile diarrhea. The various infectious causes of watery and bloody diarrhea are listed below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli:
Incorrect: This elderly patient presents with large-volume watery diarrhea and a recent history of antibiotic use. She likely has Clostridioides difficile diarrhea. In contrast, enteroinvasive Escherichia coli causes bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Shigella sonnei:
Incorrect: Shigella sonnei typically causes bloody diarrhea. In contrast, this patient has large-volume watery diarrhea in the setting of recent antibiotic use, which is more concerning for Clostridioides difficile infection.  
❌ Entamoeba histolytica:
Incorrect: Entamoeba histolytica can be acquired via the consumption of contaminated water. Patients can develop bloody diarrhea, liver abscesses, and right upper quadrant pain. However, this patient has large-volume watery diarrhea in the setting of recent antibiotic use, which is more concerning for Clostridioides difficile infection.  
❌ Giardia lamblia  :
Incorrect: Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan parasite that can cause steatorrhea. It classically occurs in campers and hikers after drinking water contaminated by Giardia cysts. However, watery diarrhea in the setting of recent antibiotic use is more concerning for Clostridioides difficile infection.
✅ Clostridioides difficile:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. His symptoms started 3 hours ago. The patient ate only a potato salad left over from a barbeque several days ago and became symptomatic a few hours later. Vital signs are stable and physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Ingestion of preformed heat stable toxin
Ingestion of bacteria that produces toxins within the gut
Ingestion of bacteria that invade the gut epithelium
Ingestion of spores that grow into bacteria in the gut

questions.solution:
This patient has food poisoning, most likely caused by Staphylococcus enterotoxin.

Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive cocci capable of causing many diseases and producing toxins. One of these toxins is Staphylococcus enterotoxin, a heat-stable toxin resistant to heat and boiling. This toxin is produced by S. aureus and is transmitted from an asymptomatic carrier into food via improper handling. If the food is left in an environment that allows the bacteria to grow (e.g. improper storage), the bacteria will start producing toxins. The most commonly implicated foods include meat, poultry, dairy products, and salads (especially those containing mayonnaise).

Food poisoning due to Staphylococcus enterotoxin quickly occurs after the patient ingests the preformed toxins. Patients develop nausea and vomiting within 2-6 hours, with or without diarrhea. This phenomenon is called fast-onset food poisoning. The symptoms are usually self-limited and resolve within 24-48 hours.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ingestion of preformed heat stable toxin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ingestion of preformed heat-labile toxin:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has food poisoning due to Staphylococcus enterotoxin, a heat-stable toxin.  
❌ Ingestion of bacteria that produces toxins within the gut:
Incorrect: This patient's symptoms developed within a few hours after ingesting the potato salad. Rapid onset food poisoning is most often due to ingestion of preformed toxins.  
❌ Ingestion of bacteria that invade the gut epithelium:
Incorrect: This patient's symptoms developed within a few hours after ingesting the potato salad. Rapid onset food poisoning is most often due to ingestion of preformed toxins.  
❌ Ingestion of spores that grow into bacteria in the gut:
Incorrect: This patient's symptoms developed within a few hours after ingesting the potato salad. Rapid onset food poisoning is most often due to ingested preformed toxins rather than bacterial spores.

questions.text: An immunologist is studying the effects of vaccines against various pathogens causing gastroenteritis. In particular, the scientist is studying the effectiveness of inactivated vaccines against Salmonella typhi. The inactivated vaccine against S. typhi most likely contains which of the following?

choices.text: mRNA snippets encoding the spike region of the microbe
Subunit vaccine containing only surface proteins

questions.solution:
Salmonella is a rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria of the Enterobacteriaceae family. After ingestion, Salmonella tends to infect M-cells of the small intestine epithelial mucosa, which transfers the bacteria to the underlying Peyer patches.

Serotypes that are typhoidal (Salmonella typhi) evade and dampen the immune response, and use host macrophages to systematically spread through the lymphatic system and bloodstream. Symptoms include a high fever with constipation followed by diarrhea, salmon-colored spots on the abdomen, and abdominal pain. A carrier state exists in which the bacterium colonizes the gallbladder of individuals with the disease, so they continue to excrete bacteria in their feces despite being asymptomatic.

Treatment can include ceftriaxone or fluoroquinolone, but antibiotics can prolong fecal excretion of the pathogen. Vaccines exist, with an oral live-attenuated vaccine and intramuscular vaccine containing the Vi capsular polysaccharide.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Salmonella typhi-secreted toxins:
Incorrect: Toxoid vaccines are used against Clostridium tetani, not against Salmonella typhi.  
❌ Type B capsular polysaccharide:
Incorrect: Vaccines against specific strains of Haemophilus influenzae include the type B capsular polysaccharide as part of its formulation.  
❌ mRNA snippets encoding the spike region of the microbe:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the Pfizer-Biontech and Moderna vaccines against SARS-CoV-2.  
❌ Subunit vaccine containing only surface proteins:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the subunit vaccine involved in protection against hepatitis B.
✅ Vi capsular polysaccharide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider for evaluation of foul-smelling diarrhea that has been ongoing for the past week. Her symptoms developed after she returned from a hiking trip in the Appalachian mountains. During the trip, the patient consumed smoked meats and freshwater from ponds and streams. Since returning, the patient has noticed that her stools are hard to flush and float in the toilet bowl. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Stool is guaiac negative. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with foul-smelling stools that are hard to flush and float in the toilet bowl. In addition, she consumed freshwater from streams and ponds during the hiking trip. In combination, the patient’s history is concerning for Giardia lamblia infection.  

G. lamblia is a flagellated protozoan parasite. Infection classically occurs in campers and hikers who consume water contaminated by Giardia cysts. Once ingested, the cysts will hatch and Giardia can reproduce in the small intestines. Infection causes shortening of the intestinal microvilli, thereby leading to diarrhea secondary to malabsorption and hypersecretion.  

Clinically, patients present with steatorrhea, flatulence, abdominal pain, and nausea/vomiting. In rare cases, patients can develop a fever.  

Giardia infection can be diagnosed via stool microscopy (revealing multinucleated Giardia cysts), antigen detection assays, or nucleic acid amplification assays.  

Option Analysis

✅ Giardia lamblia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Shigella sonnei:
Incorrect: This patient presents with foul-smelling stools that are hard to flush and float in the toilet bowl. These findings are suggestive of steatorrhea. Shigella sonnei, however, does not typically cause steatorrhea.  
❌ Clostridium difficile:
Incorrect: Clostridium difficile can cause foul-smelling watery diarrhea and is associated with recent antibiotic use. In contrast, this patient has stools that are difficult to flush and float in the toilet bowl, which is suggestive of steatorrhea. Moreover, the patient consumed unfiltered freshwater during the hiking trip. These findings are more concerning for Giardia lamblia infection.  
❌ Tropheryma whipplei  :
Incorrect: Tropheryma whipplei is the cause of tropical sprue, which manifests with chronic diarrhea, arthralgia, and neurological symptoms secondary to vitamin deficiency. The condition tends to affect middle-aged individuals who recently traveled to tropical areas.  
❌ Entamoeba histolytica:
Incorrect: Entamoeba histolytica can be acquired via the consumption of contaminated water. Patients can develop bloody diarrhea, liver abscesses, and right upper quadrant pain. However, infection by Entamoeba histolytica does not typically cause steatorrhea.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office to evaluate bloody diarrhea. The patient’s parent states, “I don’t know if it is something he ate, but over half his bowel movements fill the toilet with blood. He had a fever yesterday as well.” Which of the following is the most likely pathogen implicated in this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bloody diarrhea – a key clinical differentiator when attempting to decipher the causative organism. Of the pathogens listed above, only Campylobacter jejuni is known to cause bloody diarrhea. The table below classifies several organisms based on the type of diarrhea. In general, most pathogens associated with bloody diarrhea are considered forms of invasive diarrhea or dysentery. These infections are commonly associated with fever and abdominal pain as well.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Campylobacter jejuni:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clostridioides difficile:
Incorrect: Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile causes watery diarrhea, not bloody diarrhea. Moreover, this patient does not have risk factors for C. difficile such as recent antibiotic use or hospitalization.  
❌ Rotavirus:
Incorrect: Rotavirus is a common cause of profuse, watery diarrhea in children, but not bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Vibrio cholerae:
Incorrect: Vibrio cholerae is endemic to developing regions and commonly occurs after consuming contaminated water (or seafood). It does not cause bloody diarrhea.  
❌ Heliobacter pylori:
Incorrect: Heliobacter pylori is a major cause of gastritis and peptic ulcer disease but does not cause bloody diarrhea.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to difficulty ambulation for the past four days. The patient reports “stumbling” and states, “I feel like my legs are getting weaker and weaker.” The patient has no other medical history and takes no medications daily. Vitals are within normal limits. Neurologic exam is notable for 3/5 strength in the lower extremities bilaterally and a decreased patellar and Achilles reflex bilaterally. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. This patient’s condition was most likely preceded by infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Guillain-Barré syndrome, or acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, is an autoimmune condition that results from demyelination of Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system. This condition typically manifests with ascending, bilateral weakness of the lower extremities. Patients can develop respiratory failure if the diaphragm becomes involved. The disease is thought to be secondary to molecular mimicry, where an inciting agent serves as a nidus for the immune system towards self-demyelination.

While there is no specific causal link to a pathogen, there is an association between prior infection with Campylobacter jejuni and the subsequent development of Guillain-Barré syndrome. Approximately two-thirds of patients have a history of an antecedent respiratory or gastrointestinal infection. Previous Campylobacter jejuni infection has also been implicated in developing reactive arthritis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Campylobacter jejuni:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Heliobacter pylori:
Incorrect: Heliobacter pylori is a major cause of gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, not Guillain-Barré syndrome.  
❌ Neisseria meningitidis:
Incorrect: Neisseria meningitidis can cause meningococcemia characterized by meningitis and a diffuse, purpuric rash.  
❌ Treponema pallidum:
Incorrect: Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, can cause tabes dorsalis characterized by gait ataxia and degeneration of the dorsal column fibers.  
❌ Hepatitis C virus:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C virus is associated with the development of cirrhotic liver disease and hepatocellular carcinoma, not Guillain-Barré syndrome

He has not experienced abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or fatigue. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 30-pack-year smoking history. The patient also has a history of intravenous drug use and was undomiciled in his early 30s. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. choices.text: Inhibition of virion release from infected cells
Prevention of viral entry into the target cell

questions.solution:
This patient has elevated liver enzymes and hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection, and the patient is started on interferon-alpha (IFN-α) therapy.

Interferons (IFNs) are cytokines that exhibit a broad spectrum of antiviral activities and immunomodulating and antiproliferative properties. Currently, only two types of interferons are available for clinical use: IFNα2A and IFNα2B.

The selective antiviral action of IFN-α is primarily due to its ability to activate host cell ribonucleases that preferentially degrade viral mRNA. IFN-α also promotes the formation of natural killer cells that destroy liver cells infected by HCV. It is usually given either as an intramuscular or subcutaneous injection. Sometimes INFs can be provided in pegylated IFN (i.e. IFN plus polyethylene glycol).

IFNs are used in the treatment of both chronic HBV and HCV infections. When treating HCV infection, IFNs are used either as monotherapy or in combination with other antiviral medications such as ribavirin. Other indications include herpes virus infection, papillomavirus infection, and Kaposi sarcoma occurring in the setting of HIV infection.

Side effects of IFN-α include flu-like symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting), bone marrow suppression leading to neutropenia and thrombocytopenia, neurotoxicity (e.g., sleepiness, depression, behavioral disturbances), and liver dysfunction leading to elevated liver enzymes. It can also cause alopecia, which is more common in children.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Activation of host cell ribonuclease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of viral protease activity:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors are drugs that inhibit the action of HIV-1 protease, an enzyme that cleaves precursor proteins into smaller fragments. These fragments are needed for viral growth, infectivity, and replication. Examples of protease inhibitors include ritonavir and indinavir.  
❌ Inhibition of virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that can treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Prevention of viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.  
❌ Inhibition of viral DNA replication:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, no additional nucleotides can be added, and DNA synthesis stops. Interferon-ɑ, however, works via a different mechanism of action.

The patient frequently experiences fatigue and dull abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for a diagnosis of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus in her 40s, but these conditions remain untreated. The patient received a blood transfusion several decades ago following complicated childbirth. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on a combination of sofosbuvir and daclatasvir. Daclatasvir acts via the inhibition of which of the following?

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, dull abdominal pain, elevated hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection. The patient is started on sofosbuvir and daclatasvir.

Daclatasvir is an NS5A inhibitor often used in combination with sofosbuvir to treat HCV infection. NS5A is a membrane-associated phosphoprotein part of the HCV RNA replication complex and is essential for viral replication and assembly. Inhibition of this phosphoprotein prevents HCV RNA replication. Other NS5A inhibitors include elbasvir, ledipasvir, ombitasvir, and velpatasvir.

Side effects associated with NS5A inhibitor use include mild to moderate headache, fatigue, and gastrointestinal irritation. Daclatasvir is primarily metabolized through CYP3A metabolism and should not be given strong inducers or inhibitors of this enzyme.  

Option Analysis

❌ Viral DNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Hepatitis medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA and RNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, viral polymerase, and the synthesis of genetic material stops, no additional nucleotides can be added. In contrast, daclatasvir works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ HCV-encoded proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Ribavirin is an antiviral medication that inhibits viral production of guanine nucleotides through competitive inhibition of inosine monophosphate (IMP) dehydrogenase. It is usually used as an adjunct to interferon therapy.  
❌ Virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that blocks the enzyme neuraminidase. NAIs can be used to treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting for the past 12-hours. The abdominal pain was initially dull and diffuse but subsequently progressed to a sharp pain in the right lower abdomen. Medical history is significant for epilepsy and asthma. Temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 122/62 mmHg. Physical examination reveals right lower quadrant abdominal tenderness. Bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis with a leftwards shift. An abdominal CT scan is notable for a distended and edematous appendix with surrounding soft tissue stranding. Emergent surgery under general anesthesia is scheduled. Which one of the following anesthetic agents is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has acute appendicitis, and an emergency appendectomy is planned under general anesthesia. Enflurane is contraindicated in this patient, given her history of epilepsy.

Inhaled anesthetics include nitrous oxide, which acts as an NMDA receptor antagonist, and halogenated anesthetics (e.g., halothane, enflurane, methoxyflurane, desflurane), that act as NMDA receptor antagonists and GABA receptor agonists.

Inhaled anesthetics can cause vasodilation, cardiovascular depression,  respiratory depression, increased cerebral blood flow, and increased intracranial pressure. They also blunt the sympathetic response to hypoxia, so monitoring arterial oxygen saturation after administering these medications is essential. Other side effects include hepatotoxicity (halothane), nephrotoxicity (methoxyflurane), lowered seizure threshold (enflurane), and expansion of trapped gas within body cavities (nitric oxide).

All halogenated anesthetics can cause a life-threatening condition called malignant hyperthermia. The anesthetic agents cause an increased release of calcium stored in muscle cells, resulting in relentless muscle contractions and heat generation. Symptoms of malignant hyperthermia include muscle rigidity, rhabdomyolysis, hyperthermia, metabolic acidosis, and tachycardia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Propofol:
Incorrect: Propofol is a parenteral anesthetic that potentiates the effects of GABAA on its receptors. It can cause vasodilation, cardiovascular depression, and propofol infusion syndrome. However, this patient has no contraindications to propofol administration.  
❌ Methoxyflurane:
Incorrect: Methoxyflurane is known to cause nephrotoxicity in susceptible individuals. It is not contraindicated in patients with epilepsy or asthma.  
✅ Enflurane:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Halothane:
Incorrect: Halothane is an anesthetic. Halothane dilates the airways so that it can be used in patients with asthma. However, it is no longer used in developed countries since it can cause severe and potentially fatal hepatotoxicity.  
❌ Ketamine:
Incorrect: Ketamine is a parenteral anesthetic that blocks NMDA receptors. It is known to stimulate the sympathetic nervous system and cause dissociative amnesia. However, it can be safely used in patients with epilepsy and asthma.

A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of a positive urine pregnancy test. Past medical history is significant for chronic hepatitis C infection and seasonal allergies. The patient has not seen a physician in many years and currently does not take any medications. She has a remote history of intravenous drug use when she was undomiciled in her early 20s. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following medication regimens should be avoided in this patient?
